title-group.article-title: A Penalized Likelihood Approach to Rotation of Principal Components

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2005 American Statistical Association, the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and the Interface Foundation of North America

abstract.p: A new paradigm for enhancing the interpretability of principal components through rotation is presented within the framework of penalized likelihood. The rotated components are computed as the maximizers of a Gaussian-based profile log-likelihood function plus a penalty term defined by a standard rotation criterion. This method enjoys a number of advantages over other methods for principal component rotation, notably (1) the rotation specifically targets ill-defined principal components, which may benefit the most from rotation, and (2) the connection with likelihood allows assessment of the fidelity of the rotated components to the data, thereby guiding the choice of penalty parameter. The method is illustrated with an application to a small functional dataset. Efficient computation of the penalized likelihood solution is possible using recently developed algorithms for optimization under orthogonality constraints.
